Under the OCSLA, the DOI must create five-year programs for oil and gas lease sales in U.S. waters, balancing energy supply and environmental protection. The BOEM leads this process, which involves multiple drafts, economic and environmental analysis, and approval by the Secretary of the Interior and Congress. NEPA requirements are also followed in the planning process. The planning process for oil and gas lease sales in U.S. waters includes a programmatic environmental impact statement (PEIS) as required by NEPA. Public comments are addressed in both the PEIS and the five-year program. The finalized program cannot be revised without restarting the process, but scheduled sales could potentially be canceled during implementation based on environmental review requirements. BOEM released the final version of its oil and gas leasing program for 2017-2022 on November 18, 2016. The final oil and gas leasing program for 2017-2022 was approved by former Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell on January 17, 2017. The program includes 11 lease sales on the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS), with 10 in the Gulf of Mexico region and 1 in the Alaska region. Sales in the Atlantic and Pacific regions were not included in the final program. Congress plays an active role in the planning process for the five-year programs, although their review does not include approval or disapproval of the program. Congress plays an active role in the planning process for the five-year offshore oil and gas leasing programs. Members can influence the program by submitting public comments, evaluating the program in committee oversight hearings, and introducing legislation to set or alter program terms. The Draft Proposed Program (DPP) represents the initial proposal for lease sales in the upcoming five-year period. It analyzes all OCS planning areas for leasing, identifies areas proposed for lease sales, and includes a preliminary schedule. BOEM published the DPP for 2017-2022 on January 29, 2015, receiving over 1 million comments. Following the DPP, BOEM issues a notice of intent (NOI) for a programmatic environmental impact statement (PEIS) and seeks public input. Subsequently, a Proposed Program (PP) is published after further analysis and consideration of public comments. After analyzing the lease sale areas proposed in the DPP and considering public comments, BOEM publishes a Proposed Program (PP) for the five-year period. The PP refines locations and timing for OCS oil and gas lease sales. It is accompanied by a draft PEIS analyzing the identified leasing areas.
